key_points: Meghan Markle gave birth to her second child, Lilibet 'Lili' Diana Mountbatten-Windsor, on June 4.
The name 'Lilibet' is after Queen Elizabeth II, whose family nickname is Lilibet, and 'Diana' after Princess Diana.
The article questions the choice of naming their child after members of the royal family which they accused of racial abuse.
Meghan and Harry had previously detailed their struggles with racism within the Royal Family in an interview with Oprah.
They left the Royal Family citing racism, lack of support, and concerns over mental health.
The choice of the baby's name raises questions about Harry and Meghan's stance against the royal institution and traditions.
The article suggests a contradiction between criticizing the royal institution and naming their child after its current head.
It posits that naming their daughter after the Queen sends a message of support to the royal family.
The writer argues that real change against racism and the monarchy requires more than just personal reconciliation with the family.
The article concludes that Harry and Meghan should not be seen as heroes in the anti-racism movement but as family members seeking reconciliation.
